bibl.title: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, April 16, 1901

div1.p: Louise Kean writes about the use of fumigation against yellow fever, the quarantine in New Orleans, and Jefferson Randolph Kean being placed in charge of the finances for the Yellow Fever Commission.

div1.head: Letter from Louise Young Kean to Mrs. Mason Young, April 16, 1901
div1.p:
I was so glad
to hear the news about
Tom. How I wish I had
been there when he walk-
ed in! Tell him to please
go to New Orleans via Havana.
If those State health officers
would only be truly scientif-
ic and stop the fool busi-
ness of fumigating clothes
for yellow fever prevention
Tom really could make us
a little visit. But the
New Orleans quarantine is
already down, and as rigid
as ever.
Did you ever know any-
thing so heart rending
as that performance of
the Rawlins. I hardly dare
to hope my boxes may turn
up on the Sedgewick, and
I do not dare to contem-
plate what will happen
if they don't. I needed
stockings two months ago!
Besides the box from Helen
Miss Bacon had sent me
one too, containing cake
and all sorts of nice things.
The Sedgewick is going
back by way of Porto
Rico. Mama is delighted
at the prospect of seeing
San Juan, and so is Gertrude.

Four days ago Rannie and I would have
hooted at the idea that we were not
settled here for the summer, infact Rannie
thought he could stay here as long as
he pleased, but - Tuesday Major Greble
came out to luncheon and told Rannie
Gen. Wood wished him to take Major G.'s
place in charge of charities and hospitals.
It was only a year ago Rannie turned
all of his share of that business over to the
Major chortling with joy at having gotten
rid of it; and now here is Major Greble
going to West Point and Rannie back
into the charities, ten times worse than
he was before! Rannie did not want
to take it for tho! he knew it was a
compliment he likewise knew we could
not afford to live in town, and the
very thought of the Maestranza made
me sick. So we talked it over with our
“Lady from Phila”. Capt. Slocum and ar-
rived at no satisfactory conclusion so
Monday Rannie went in to see Major
Greble, who marched him straight to
Gen. Wood. The Gen. was perfectly lovely,
said he was the man
he wanted and asked
what were his objections.
When Rannie said he
could not live in town
on his pay he replied
“why not live at Colum-
bia?” Rannie explained
how there were no quar-
ters, so the Gen. said
“I'll build you a set”! Then
Rannie feebly remonstrated
that he knew nothing
of financial administration
but the Gen. said “you
know as much as I did
when I came to Cuba, all
the experience I had
ever had was in trying
to make $133.33 last
through the month!”
So then Rannie had
nothing more to say,
tho' I know his heart
yearns over his beloved
hospital and he simply
hates to give it up. I
am perfectly happy as
long as we are to live
out here, for I could not
possibly have spent the
summer in town with
the children. Rannie
will have to go off in
a little while around
the island with Major
Greble, and then as Gen.
Wood said to him “Oh
you'll like it you will
be away from home at
least one week in every month.” I know
what to look forward to! But it is
a very important position, and it is a
good thing to be on the staff of a
rising young general.

I saw Will Renie today at the Palace.
He did not know me at first. He looks
the same as ever, but I only had a
minute's conversation with him.

I suppose now Tommy is home you have
recovered from all your ailments, so I hope
you will feel able to write me soon.

Letters from the family have been rather
few and far between lately. Give my
love to them all. I wonder if Tom got
my picture I sent him a little while
ago. Bobs and Martha are very well.
I wonder if Doll can't hunt up some books
for me to read Martha. If some of you
would go to Brentance's and select some
things and have them send the bill
I would be very grateful.
